JUDGES: András Sajó;David Thór Björgvinsson;Françoise Tulkens;Guido Raimondi
TEXT: The applicants ( see attached table ) are NORP nationals . They are represented before the ORG by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent PERSON , and their Co - Agent , PERSON .

The applicants are all graduates in medicine and surgery . They have been undergoing a specialisation course “ medici in formazione specialistica/ medici specializzandi ” , on a scholarship for DATE at ORG in GPE .
The details about the applicants’ registration dates and the length of their courses can be found in the attached table .

In accordance with section CARDINAL of legislative decree no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE ( “ Law no . CARDINAL ” ) , they have been receiving remuneration of MONEY ( ORG ) per year for their academic work and practical work in hospitals . This amount remained the same throughout DATE of service until DATE , notwithstanding that originally the law provided for adjustment according to inflation and a tri - annual revision . The latter had to be in accordance with a yet - to - be - enacted law on budget allocation ( section CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL ) which was never enacted . Moreover , pay rises provided by the ordinary law had been blocked by the Government by means of various legal provisions . It was only through the “ legge finanziaria ” of DATE that these pay rises were provided for , but only to take effect from DATE . As a consequence the applicants , up to DATE , allegedly lost PERCENT of what their salaries would have been if adjusted .

During their service the applicants were not covered by an obligatory insurance and were not registered with ORG ( “ ORG ” ) , an NORP welfare entity , the latter notwithstanding that they claimed that their right to registration and cover by ORG had been provided for by Law no . CARDINAL and was to be managed by ORG . The provisions applicable to a contract of work - training ( formazione - lavoro ) ( see section DATE ( CARDINAL ) of PERSON no . CARDINAL ) were section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of PERSON no . CARDINAL of DATE as amended by LAW . CARDINAL of DATE and LAW no . CARDINAL , which expressly provided for the payment of contributions . Social security cover was also due to medici specializzandi as transpired from section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of PERSON no . CARDINAL ( see Relevant domestic law for legal texts ) .

According to section DATE of Law no . CARDINAL , such social security cover would enter into force upon the enactment of the apposite legal provisions on budget allocation . However , for DATE after the applicants took up their functions the relevant provisions were not enacted . Thus , they remained without social security cover for the entire period of service or DATE .

In DATE by means of the “ legge finanziaria ” , PERSON no . CARDINAL was amended , in that medici specializzandi were to be governed by contracts of specialist training “ di formazione specialistica ” and no longer contracts of work - training . This law expressly provided for the registration with the INPS of medici specializzandi , under the provisions applicable to all categories of self - employed . Section CARDINAL of PERSON no . CARDINAL was amended accordingly ( see Relevant domestic law ) . However , social security cover for the medici specializzandi was provided for only with effect from DATE . Thus , the applicants remained excluded from such benefits entirely or up to DATE , respectively .

On DATE the first CARDINAL applicants ( application no . CARDINAL ) and another CARDINAL individuals in their position instituted proceedings before ORG claiming that they had been denied social security cover and “ salary ” adjustments as a result of the failure to enact the law containing the relevant budgetary provisions . Such an omission was also contrary to ORG regulations on the matter .

By a judgment of DATE filed with the relevant registry on DATE their claims were rejected . ORG considered of relevance only the legislation in force at the time and not subsequent legislation . Distinguishing between medici in formazione specialistica and “ medico strutturato ” , it held that the relevant ORG directive ( Council Directive CARDINAL/CARDINAL/EEC of DATE to facilitate the free movement of doctors and the mutual recognition of their diplomas , certificates and other evidence of formal qualifications ) left issues related to medici in formazione specialistica in a lacuna , the directive concentrating on reciprocal recognition of qualifications , freedom of movement of the profession and the coordination between GPE of the exercise of the medical profession . In particular , it did not provide specific criteria in relation to the principle of “ appropriate remuneration ” . In consequence it could not be said that the ORG directive created a right in respect of specific salaries for medici in formazione specialistica . Neither was it possible to derive that right from sections DATE and CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL , which aimed to transpose the said directive into national law . The limited time during which these provisions were in force before they were suspended by the same measures also suspending sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL did not allow for the creation of a substantive and actionable right on the part of the applicants . The stipulation of a contract of “ DATE training ” could not allow medici specializzandi to acquire a right to remuneration adjustment and social security cover as provided in sections DATE and CARDINAL of the said law which was suspended by express statutory norms , until the enactment of budgetary provisions . Neither did it appear that in the short time ( a bit DATE ) before the latter suspension , the relevant decree “ ORG dei NORP ” ( PERSON ) , which would have defined the work - training contract ’s scheme , had been adopted . Without this there could not be any activation of the norm . It follows that in the absence of the ORG and relevant budgetary provisions , the failure of universities to stipulate “ work - training ” contracts could not give rise to any consequences , since LAW , CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the said law never became operational .

An appeal is still pending . However , the first , second and third applicants claim that in view of current jurisprudence ( see relevant domestic law ) it is unlikely that such proceedings will be successful . Similarly , all the remaining applicants have not undertaken any domestic proceedings for the same reasons .

However , the increments provided for by LAW no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE were blocked by a series of legislative decrees and by - laws , dated DATE , DATE and DATE .

At the relevant time a work - training contract was governed by the provisions of section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of legislative decree no . CARDINAL of DATE , as amended by PERSON no . CARDINAL of DATE , which read as follows :

“ For persons employed under a work - training contract , the ORG contribution is a fixed rate corresponding to that for apprentices according to PERSON no . CARDINAL of DATE and its successive amendments , bearing in mind the employees’ contribution as provided for the majority of employees . ”
The relevant amendment provided for a reduction in the welfare contributions vis - à - vis that of normal subordinate employees , equating it to that of apprentices .

In the judgment Commission v. GPE , case CARDINAL of DATE , ORG ( “ the ECJ ” ) held that GPE had failed to transpose the relevant directives in so far as it had failed to provide for “ appropriate remuneration ” of medici in formazione specialistica .

Subsequently , in DATE the relevant directives were transposed into NORP law , namely PERSON no . CARDINAL of DATE ( see above ) , which provided for the detailed conditions relevant to funding in the sector . Its section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) provided that adjustments should be integrated DATE .

According to section CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL of DATE ( see above ) the scholarship amounted to ORG DATE , it was to be annually increased by the inflation rate and re - determined triennially , by ministerial decree , in accordance with the minimum established salary increases provided by the collective bargaining of ORG medical staff . Subsequently , this was amended by PERSON no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE , sections DATE ( see above ) . By Law no . CARDINAL of DATE ( “ legge finanziaria ” ) scholarship awards were raised and social security cover was introduced as from DATE .

Up to the enactment of the relevant budgetary provisions in accordance with PERSON no . CARDINAL , the law applicable in relation to budgetary adjustments was section CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE . However , by means of a series of legislative measures , the possibility of such pay rises had been blocked .

In this respect the Constitutional Court judgment of DATE PERSON studi PERSON – held that the legislative blocking of automatic adjustment of scholarships for medici specializzandi had been legitimate . The measures adapted the plaintiff ’s situation to a common principle present in the public and private sector , namely the counteraction of the increase in the cost of living by contractual flexibility . Thus , the exceptional exclusion of scholarships from adjustments according to the rate of inflation , for a limited period of time , was not unreasonable or discriminatory . It was part and parcel of a complex group of norms in the health sector aiming to impede , for the same period of time , all pay rises arising from automatic salary increments .

In relation to the matter at issue in the present applications , ORG held that PERSON no . CARDINAL , in so far as it stipulated an DATE contract of training , was not operative at the relevant time , it having become so only in DATE by means of the legge finanziaria . The application of section CARDINAL of the said law had been suspended by means of section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of PERSON no . CARDINAL of DATE . The latter provision amended section CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL , establishing that its provisions will apply only on the entry into force of legislative budgetary measures ( which before DATE had not been introduced ) . Up to that future date , PERSON no . CARDINAL of DATE was applicable , which provided for the payment of a scholarship for medici specializzandi . It held that , as acknowledged by the ECJ , the relevant ORG Directive did not indicate a definition of appropriate remuneration , nor did it establish criteria for the calculation of such remuneration . Thus , there was no unconditional obligation on the ORG in this respect . Moreover , the said directive did not oblige member GPE to stipulate contracts of subordinate work with specialising doctors , as the same objective could be achieved by means of other forms of contract and the relevant remuneration through different methods . In consequence , national law was not in contradiction with the ORG directive .
The plaintiffs were covered by Law no . CARDINAL and as previously stated by ORG the functions undertaken by medici specializzandi did not constitute subordinate labour .

As to the adjustments of the scholarship award ( section CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL ) Law no . CARDINAL of DATE and successive laws blocked any adjustments . This matter had been examined by ORG of DATE – Bartolomei c. Univ . studi PERSON altri , which found it to be legitimate ( see above ) .

In relation to the same subject matter at issue in the present applications , ORG rejected the complaints on the basis that the ORG directive was generic as to what constituted appropriate remuneration . Moreover , such rights could not have arisen from domestic constitutional criteria , as the function at issue did not equate to subordinate labour , it being a different relationship connected to training .
In relation to the same subject matter at issue in the present applications , ORG rejected the claims of the medici specializzandi for adjustment of their remuneration for the period DATE .
